guide.title: Fire Safety Guide
guide.intro: Practical tips on where, how many and why to install fire safety equipment at home, in the office and at warehouses.

cta.title: Need help choosing?
cta.subtitle: We'll prepare a quote, consult you and suggest the optimal set.

apartment.title: Apartment
recs: OP-5/OP-10 near exit or in the kitchen; mounting ~1.5 m to handle, clear access.
OU-3/OU-5 near electrical panel or server nook — safe for electricity.
Smoke detectors in corridor/bedrooms, audible alert.
Fire blanket in the kitchen, heat-resistant gloves.
Keep evacuation paths clear; no clutter.

office.title: Office
recs: Distribute OP-5/OP-10 across floor/levels per norms; near entrances and printer rooms.
OU-5 near electrical panels/server room; avoid using CO2 on Class A (paper/furniture).
Fire cabinets/hose reels per design, keep access free and marked.
Fire alarm and PA system; schedule regular checks.
Evacuation plan and staff training; first aid supplies.

warehouse.title: Warehouse
recs: OP-10/OP-50 ensuring uniform coverage; OP-50 trolleys for racking aisles.
Powder suppression modules (MPP) for local high‑risk zones.
Hydrants/cabinets according to design; constant availability.
Safety signs, aisle markings, keep exits unobstructed.
Automatic alarm, PA, regular drills.

maintenance.title: Maintenance
recs: Recharge after any activation and per service interval in the passport.
Check seal and pressure weekly (needle in green zone).
Store dry, protect from heat/frost; mount on a proper bracket.
Keep service logbook and attach reports.
Pressure‑test hoses periodically; watch for leaks.

signage.title: Signage and Evacuation
recs: Place photoluminescent exit signs and directional arrows.
Mark locations of extinguishers, cabinets, call points/phones.
Evacuation plans at visible spots; update when layout changes.
Keep aisles clear; emergency doors unlocked during operation.
Conduct evacuation drills 1–2 times a year.

faq.q: What’s the difference between OP and OU?
faq.a: OP — powder, versatile for A/B/C/E classes, leaves residue. OU — CO2 for electrical equipment and liquids, no residue, hazardous in tight rooms (asphyxiation risk).
Home: OP‑5/OP‑10. Office: OP‑5–10 by area/category norms. Warehouse: OP‑10/OP‑50 and trolleys. Consider fire classes and accessibility.
CO2 is effective on electrical equipment and liquids; for Class A (paper/wood) prefer powder/water/foam. CO2 dissipates fast, reignition possible.
A — solids (paper, wood), B — liquids, C — gases, E — electrical under voltage. Match extinguisher to class.
After any use; by service interval in passport; if pressure is out of green zone; upon damage.
Dry place, away from heat, accessible; mounted on bracket, intact seal, pressure in green zone.

faq.q: Are signs and evac plans required?
faq.a: For offices/warehouses — yes: plans, photoluminescent exit signs, arrows, equipment signs.

faq.q: What to provide for electrical room/server room?
faq.a: OU‑3/5 nearby, OP as backup; smoke/heat detectors, PA; keep room tidy, fire‑rated doors.
Accessibility, labeling, completeness (hose, nozzle, valve), no twists/leaks; periodic hose pressure‑tests.
Initial briefing at onboarding and evacuation drills 1–2 times a year (check local norms).
Certificates of conformity, product passports, service logbooks, recharge/test reports.

faq.q: Can I keep an extinguisher in a car?
faq.a: Yes, use car brackets/straps, fix to avoid rolling, observe temperature limits and pressure.
